editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: PLUTUS: A COMEDY Written in Greek By ARISTOPHANES, Tranſlated by H. H. B. Together with his Notes, and A Short Diſcourſe upon it.

q.l: Some dare affirm that Comedies may teach
More in one hour than ſome in ten can preach.

div.p: LONDON, Printed by W. G. and are to be ſold by Richard Skelton at the Hand and Bible in Ducklane, Iſaac Pridmore at the Golden Falcon neer the New-Exchange, and H. Marſh at the Prince Arms in 〈◊◊◊◊◊〉 . 1659.

div.head: Argument out of ARISTOPHANES.
div.l: CRamulus a Juſt man, but now grown low,
Conſults the Oracle his life to mend;
Follow him firſt, that doth before you go,
The anſwer is, and he your Woes ſhall end.
He haſts this happy guide to overtake,
Who Plutus proves, a man long blind;
He ſtrives at home this Friend his Gueſt to make,
And that this common joy the World may find:
Of Eſculapius he by Sacrifice
Obtains his long loſt ſight for to reſtore;
That ſo the Fools and Knaves, and not the Wiſe,
And Virtuous, hereafter ſhould be poore.
O Jupiter! what a hard age is this to be a Servant in,
Eſpecially to a fooliſh Maſter; if a ſervant ſhall
Give never ſo good Counſel, his word will not
Be taken, his Maſter thinks himſelf wiſer, and ſo
His Family is bound to ſuffer with him; for 'tis the miſchief
We are not Maſters of our own bodies,
But they that buy us; and not much unlike
This Caſe of ours, and ſlavery, is that my Maſter is in now

By Apollo, with his ambiguous anſwers from his
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
three-
Footed throne: Nor is it with in juſtice I complain of him,
Who though he be counted a great Prophet and a Phyſician,
Yet he hath ſent my Maſter from him ſick,
And I think half mad with Melancholy,
For yonder he follows a blind man ſtep by ſtep;
I have heard of ſeeing men leading the blind,
But never of blind men leading thoſe that can ſee before:
And ask him what he means by it,
I can no longer hold my tongue, Enter Cramulus.
Unleſs you will tell me why we follow this Fellow thus;
Nay, I will vex you, for I know you dare not ſtrike me,

Whileſt I carry your Bag.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Ornaments he carried along with him for to we 〈…〉 in ſacrifice.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: No, yet if you be troubleſome I ſhall take Away the Bag, and then beat you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Well, I will not be quieted untill I know who this is.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p:
Well, becauſe thou art in my eſteeme the moſt Faithful and ſecret
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , to hide, uſed here ſceptically for the craft of a thief, for 〈…〉 had uſed 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 before alſo, which had been enough. of all my Family, I will not Conceal this from thee, thou knoweſt I have lived
Religiouſly with both Gods and Men, and yet alwayes have Lived poor and miſerable.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: 'Tis very True.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p:
And yet they that Rob the very
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Jeroſolumitas, and thence Iſraelitas, I wonder at the Etymology. Churches, the Rethoricians, Sycophants, every Raſcal grows rich.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I grant you.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p:
I went therefore to conſult the Oracle about my Son, that ſince my own miſerable life is now almoſt Spent,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . An arrow ſhot out of a bow, ſo Pſal. 127. v. 5. Children like arrows in the hands of Gyants. and paſt redreſs, whether it were not beſt for him To change his manners betimes, ſhake off his honour, and Learn to be as cunning a knave as he can; For 'tis that onely conduces to living well.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And what ſaid Phaebus to this?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.l: That you ſhall hear; he plainly told me,
That whoſoever I met firſt, I ſhould never
Leave him 'till I had got him into my houſe,
If it were poſſible.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And this I warrant was he.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: The very ſame.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
You need not have obeyed the Oracles Counſel, you
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Left handed, or, Mal droite, as the French have it. ſimple fellow in this; for the words carry enough in Them, for follow the man you firſt met, implies As much, as let your Son live by the ordinary cuſtomes
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Manners of his Country. And crafts he ſees others uſe, that I warrant you Was Apollo his meaning.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: How conjecture you this?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Why a blind man may ſee it,
For it profits no body in our age

To be
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Fruitfull. honeſt as you ſay, therefore ſtill do as others do,
And be as other men are.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.l: This is not all Carion, we ſhall better
Know the mind of the Oracle by enquiring
Of this fellow whence he is, and what he wants,
And how he came hither. Ex. Om.

div.stage: Enter again Plutus, Cramulus and Carion.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Come Sir, let us know who you are.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Yes, and tell us quickly too.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p:
I ſay to the Pariſh.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Coloſſ. 1.10. Fruitful to every good work.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Do you hear him?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.l: He ſpeaks to thee, thou doſt queſtion him
Too roughly; Sir, I pray you, if the fair words

Of an honeſt
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , to grieve, or
•• enas luere to suffer.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , a man unforſworn. man can prevail upon you,

Let us know your
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 Manners. qualities.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p:
I ſay unto thee
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 to weep. lament.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
Is this all the
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , ſignifies a Bird the ancient wa • of Augury being by Birds. Oracle will do for us.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.l: If you do not tell me, you ſhall have no
Cauſe to laugh, for I will deſtroy thee.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: I ſay leave me, get you gone.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: By no means.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Maſter I'le tell you what's beſt, let me lead

This blind fellow to ſome
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , to hang over. Precipice, and
I'le ſteal from him and let him break
His neck.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: do ſo.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: Hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Will you ſpeak then?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: If you ſhould know what kind a man I am, I know
You would uſe me cruelly, and not
Let me go neither.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Wee'l promiſe you the contratry, if you will ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: Lay your hands off me then firſt.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Well ſaid, 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Obſerve me well then, ſince I am forced
To reveal what I thought to have kept
Secret, I am Plutus.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.l: Then thou art the baſeſt ſordid thing alive:
Is it poſſible, art thou Plutus!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Art thou Plutus with that miſerable face

And durty cloaths,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 Squallidum. O Phaebus, Apollo, Gods and Divels!
But art thou he?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: Yes ſurely.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Thou the man?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: Even very he.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.l: But whence commeff thou in theſe
Pitiful One in Athens obſervable for Avarice. ruſty cloaths.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p:
I come from the houſe of
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , is here mea •• bathing, uſ •• much among the Greeks. Patroclus, one that Never ſince he was born could afford himſelf water.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: But how comeſt thou to ſuffer all this miſery.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Why Jupiter brought all the evils of my life upon me,
Becauſe he envied the good of mankind;

for when I was young I was
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 Threatned. adviſed to leave
Evil company, and live with the juſt and modeſt and
The learned, but Jupiter put out my eies that I might
Not diſcern them from others, ſuch an ill will

He himſelf bears to
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , The 〈…〉 men. honeſt men.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.l: And yet he himſelf receives true honour
Onely from honeſt men.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: 'Tis true.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.l: But if you had your ſight again, would you
Hereafter fly ſuch baſe company?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: For certain.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: And live amongſt honeſt men?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Without doubt, for 'tis a long time ſince I ſaw
Any ſuch.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.l: That's no wonder, for I that have my eye-ſight
Scarce ever ſaw any.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Well, now let me go, for you know all
I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.l: No, by Jove, we will now rather embrace you
More Earneſtly then ever.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: Did not I tell you what trouble you would give me?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Let me intreat you to give your ſelf into my hands For ever, and when you know me, though I ſay it, you will Not find an honeſter man.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: Yes, ſo you all ſay, but when you have injoyed me And grown rich, then you mind nothing but miſchief and Malice.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: 'Tis true, but we are not all alike.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: By Jove all one.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: A good deed to cudgel him.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.l: But that you may know how much good
You ſhall have by living with me, you ſhall

Underſtand, I hope God willing
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
• alice,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
•• abour, Malice,
〈…〉 painfull life 〈…〉 him that •• th it, as well 〈…〉 he that it is ••• eant againſt. to get you your ſight Again.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: Not of all things, I dare not ſee again.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: How is this?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: This fellow is certainly born to be Miſerable.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: If Jupiter ſhould know I were about ſuch a buſineſs, He would deſtroy me.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Can he hurt thee worſe then to let thee go wandring Up and down thus?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: I do not know what it is, but I fear him monſtrouſly.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p:
Is it poſſible? thou greateſt of all
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . cowards, Why doſt thou think Jove or his thunder would be valued At a ſtraw
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . if thou hadſt thy eyes again never ſo little A while.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: O be not ſo profane.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.l: Have patience, and I'le make it appear to thee
Thou haſt more power then Jove.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: Who me?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.l: Yes, for by what doſt thou think Jupiter
Commands all?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
By
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , properly ſilver, becauſe more uſed then gold in adorning their Temples, Herodotus Diodorus Siculus. mony, of which he hath abundance.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Pray where hath he the mony?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Of this fellow.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.l: And with what do men ſacrifice to Jove with?
Is it not with this fellow?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: And what do they ſacrifice for, but to get him?
For all their prayers are to be rich.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.l: Are not you all in all then, and if you ſay but
The word, all this will be at an end.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: How can that be?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Becauſe no body can ſacrifice Oxen or Sheep if You forbid them.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: Wherefore?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Why, how can he buy any thing to ſacrifice with-Out thee, ſo that you ſee, if Jove be troubleſome, You know what to do with him.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: Is it with me and for me, ſay you then, that men Sacrifice?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: I ſay ſo by Jove, and moreover, whatever is famous Or eſteemed amongſt men, thou art Author of, For money rules all.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Why, you ſee with a little money I am bought
And made a Slave of, becauſe I had none my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p:
And you know the Corinthian Women when poverty
Tempts them are ſeldome perſwaded, but if mony be
To be had, then they are brought to reaſon
And to be
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 a better ſort of courtiſans, amicas. active, that makes them Wagtailes.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: And the ſame thing the Boyes do for reward,
Not for love.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.l: Nay, but you ſpeak of thoſe that are of low
Quality, for the beſt ſort of theſe ſcorn mony.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What do they ſeek elſe?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p:
Why, a good horſe or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Moſt elegant bawdery in the Greek, it ſignifies to ſtir or wrigle the tail. hounds is a tempting preſent.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: They are too proud perhaps to take mony, and
Therefore under this pretext hide their
Avarice, but 'tis all one, mony and monies worth.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.l: All arts, all cheats are invented for thy ſake,
Plutus; the one is a Cobler, th' other a Cutler,

Th' other a Carpenter, another a And ſo in another place 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Nates vel clu
• s denudare. Gold-melter
For thy ſake even of that gold thou gaveſt him;

And as arts, ſo are all
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Scortum, Cynaedus, from the word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , to ſell▪ thefts ſtill,
For thy ſake, men taken in adultery

Have their
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , hunting bounds, he means here mens Sons of quality were onely to be debauched by preſents moſt tempting to youth: So Petronius to Gayton, Gallum pagnaciſſimum dabo. torture given to them.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: What a wretch am I, who till now never
Knew all this!

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: What makes the King of Perſia From 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , a Wall, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , ſignifies him that commits all manner of thefts or Burglaries. triumph ſo Think you?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
What are all
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , to pluck or ſhake, thence 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , the Adulterers formerly were condemned to have the hairs torn from the privy parts, and he means none ſhut for mony would undertake ſuch an office. Conventions and Sects of men Gathered for?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.l: And tell me what mans and furniſhes
The Greek Navies that are ſet out?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Or what ſuſtaines the great Corinthian Armies?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: And gives The word is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , a Metaphor taken from the ſetting out of hair. Pamphilus ſuch cauſe of ſorrow?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Yes, and Belonopolus his partner.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: What makes Argyrius I pray you fart as he goes Up and down?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l:
And for thy ſake Pheliſius
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 conventions of men, it may now properly enough relate to what we call 〈…〉 Church. An Uſurer, who it ſeems had all his wealth taken from him, and put i •••• the publick ſtock. tells us all his
Fine ſtories.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: And 'tis thou that aideſt the Egyptians.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And for thee Lais An Hiſtoriographer whoſe works he calls 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 fal ••• A famous Courteſan often named by the Poets. loves Philonides.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: You ſet your ſhoulder againſt Timotheus his Tower And threw it down.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Good and bad, all things are done for thy ſake.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: And in war, on that ſide the mony lies, there goes The Victory.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: Can I do all this?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Yes, by Jove, and more, of all other things there Is an end, But of enjoying thee, and that hath no ſaciety.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Of bread.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Of Banqueting.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Of Muſick

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Of Ambition.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Of Rule.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: But he that hath ten Talents of thee, would then Have twenty, then forty, and ſtill if he have not more Thinks he lives but languiſhingly.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Gentlemen, me thinks you diſcourſe well,
I fear but one thing.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: What I prethee.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: That I ſhall not be able to exerciſe all this power You give me.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: I ſee, 'tis a good ſaying, that mony is a Coward.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Nothing ſo, but a thief that came into my houſe,
Becauſe he could carry nothing away, reported I locked
My ſelf up, and hid my ſelf for fear, which I did for Providence.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.l: Well, take you no care, if you be but willing,
I'le take order you ſhall ſee as well as Lynceus.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: How can you do this, being but a mortal man?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Hope well from what I haebus but now ſaid to me, And ſhook his Lawrel at me too.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: Haſt thou him of thy Counſel alſo.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: For certain?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: Have a care what you do?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.l: Trouble not your ſelf, I'le pawn my head, I
Know how to bring this about.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And I mine too.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: We will have help enough too of all thoſe, who Becauſe they are honeſt men, ſcarce have bread to eat.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: Thoſe are but pitiful friends though me thinks.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: They will not be ſo thought when we have made Them rich again; but Carion make haſt, run.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What to do?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.l: Call all my neighbours, you will find them
Perhaps buſie at Plow, bid them leave off and be here
Preſently, tell them every one ſhall have a part
Of Plutus with us.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I am gone; but who will take care of this victuals Here, which I have bought for Dinner.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Leave that to me, and now Plutus the moſt excellent Amongſt all the Gods, enter here with me, this is my Houſe, which this day thou ſhalt make rich.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: I beſeech you excuſe me, 'tis very troubleſome to Me to go into another mans houſe, eſpecially one that I am Not acquainted with; for I never have any good by it; if I happen into a mans houſe, why then I am thruſt preſently Under ground, and ſtifled, and if any of his friends come In neceſſity, and ask for me to help him, he denies me, and Sweares he ſaw me not of I know not how long, And if I fall into a prodigal mans hands, why then I am Divided amongſt Whores, or loſt at Dice in a moment, And ſo we are both turned naked out of dores.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: You have not met with moderate men, I am one That on occaſion can ſpend, and then again ſpare, but pray You enter, I long till my Wife and my Son ſee you, who Are two, next to thee, I love beſt of all the World.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: That I eaſily believe.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Why ſhould I not ſpeak truth?Ex. om.

div.head: ACTUS SECUNDUS.
div.stage: Enter Carion and Chorus of Countrymen.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
You, all friends and neighbours, poor and laborious That have lived with us upon
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , or leeks. Onions and hard fare, I Now make haſt and make uſe of the preſent occaſion Whileſt it is offered.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p: We are ready you ſee, and make what haſt we can, Conſidering we are men toyled with labour and oppreſſed VVith Age, you cannot expect we ſhould keep pace with You, therefore tell us firſt why your maſter ſends for us?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I have told you this good while, but cannot get you To lift up your long Ears to it, that my maſter bid me tell You, that you ſhall all leave this ſorrowful careful life that You now lead, and exchange it for a pleaſant one.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p: By what means, or from whence does he hope this

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 here goes for laborious plowmen, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 with onely the change of accent ſignifies a wicked man, a man of ill fortune and men of ill manners go divers times under one name. Neighbours, my maſter will be here preſently And brings with him an old, crooked, ill-faced, unlucky, Bald, and I think, I may ſay The words uſed here are all proper to the figure it ſelf of Money, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 to defile, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , to bow or make crooked, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 miſerable, in reſpect to thoſe it makes ſo, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 wrinkled in reſpect of the ſtamp upon Coin, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 to wax bald in reſpect to its age, wearing ſmooth, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 without teeth, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Eraſm. Adag. Curt •
or Circumciſus, ſomewhere likewiſe I remember Judaeus Curtus a circumciſd Jew ſuffering to clip Mony. curtailed fellow.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p:
O thou art a golden meſſenger, what brave new Is this? by thy deſcription this muſt needs be a heap of
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , uſed for a heap of ſeed in a Cranary. Gold that's coming to us.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
Or rather a heap of all the old
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 old evils, or the firſt evils of the world. worldly evils.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p: VVell, do not think you ſhall go unpuniſhed▪ You bring us thus far upon our Crutches for nothing but to Delude us.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: You think me a man naturally ſo given to jeſt,
That I can ſay nothing in earneſt.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p: We ſhall make your bones ake by and by, you knave

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Yes, when you have took your lots out of the The wit here lies in the hiſtory and manner of chuſing Judges in Athens, who were as ma •••• as letters in the Alphabet, and governed in the ſame order that letter ſtood whi •• they drew out of the Urne, and then had given them the 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , a wand, by whi •• be jeſts at 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 a cudgel in every one of their hands, he plays with 〈…〉 word Caron and Carion his own name. Urne, and are Judges in Athens, and theſe Cudgels you have In your hands, your wands, but (g) Charon will have you in His boat before that day comes.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p: Come, you are a prating fellow to delude us thus 〈…〉 this while; in not telling plainly why your Maſter ſent For us, eſpecially knowing what buſineſs we have, and yet The haſt we have made over hedge and ditch to get hither.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Well, I will no longer conceal the buſines, my Maſter hath got Plutus into his houſe, and you are all ſent For to be made rich.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p: Is that poſſible we can be all made rich?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: As rich as you would wiſh, every one a Midas and Such goodly aſſes as he was, ſo you ſhall have.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p: How I am delighted with this! I could dance for Joy if I thought this were true.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Do ſo, you ſhall follow dancing like my Sheep, my Kids, or rather like my gray Bearded laſcivious The ſtory of Polyphemus and Gathea., Goats, And I before you will repreſent the Cyclops.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p: And we in like manner will follow you our Cyclops; But if we catch you eating the beſt Sallats and hearbs From us, as you go, and then when your belly is full fall Aſleep by the way, we ſhall order you with theſe Cudgels.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
Then will I imitate
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , ſignifies crude or rawneſs. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , to imitate a Goat, thence he calls them 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 Goates with their Pizels hanging out of their ſheaths. circen, and feed you with Hearbs that will metamorphoſe you into Swine, and then (as Ulyſſes did) feed you with See Homet the ſtory of Circean Odyſſ.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , is uſed by the Greeks, Proverbially when the unlearned follow one another. Sir reverence, and you ſhall Go grunting on, and like See Odyſſ. Malanthius ſo uſed by Ulyſſes, hoggs follow one another.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p:
And we ſeeing our Circen go about to poyſon us, Will imitate Ariſtillus, a Poet of that Age noted to be full of thoſe kind of Jeſts 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is again turned upon Carion.
Ulyſſes, and hang you up by your two Stones, and ſlit your Noſe, and then 'noint it with a Sir reverence, and you like Ariſtillus ſhall laugh and cry, Piggs follow your mother.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Well, let us leave our Jeſts, and now we are at our Journies end, every one put himſelf into his own ſhape Again; I'le go in a private way firſt, and fill my belly, And then wee'l to the great work in hand. Ex. om.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Neighbours, to ſay you are wellcome, is in my Opinion an old dull complement, therefore I will ſalute You after a new manner, and with open armes, tell you, That to recompence the haſte and pains you have taken In coming, if you will be ſtill as diligent in your own Good, you ſhall enjoy Plutus with me.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p:
Never fear, we will be as laborious and indefatigable
As Mars, and ſure if we ſhould ſtick at Trifles in this Buſineſs, we were worthy to have Plutus ſlip out of our Fingers.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I ſee Blapſidamus coming yonder, who by his haſt Me thinks comes as if he knew ſomething of this buſineſs That hath hapned to me. Ex. om.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p:
What is the matter I pray thee? how comes it to Paſs my Cramulus, thou ſhouldſt be ſo ſoon be grown rich? I could not believe it, though it was all the news At the
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , a place of reſort for newes: Theopraſtus cals it 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , meetings or clubs without wine. Barbers, by every one as ſoon as he Was ſet down in his Chair. Its newes to me if you be ſo fortunate to ſee you call all Your friends thus about you to partake with you, and againſt Our Countries cuſtome I am ſure.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Blapſidamus, I will keep nothing from thee, 'Tis true, the World is otherwiſe with me to day then it was Yeſterday, and you ſhall find it ſo, becauſe you are my friend.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p: Are you then ſo rich as it is ſaid?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p:
I ſhall be preſently if it pleaſe
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . God; but there Is ſome hazard alwayes in ſuch great works.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p: What's the danger?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: 'Tis thus.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p: Speak On freely as you have begun.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: If the matter hit right, we are all Made; if not, all Undone.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p: That's ſad, and pleaſes me not by no means, For to be ſo marvellous rich, and ſo mavellouſly affraid is Not the cuſtome of thoſe that get it honeſtly.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: How, not honeſtly?

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p: I fear. you have robb'd Apollo's Temple, And now repent you.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Apollo forbid! I never did ſuch a trick yet.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p: Come, never triffle with me, 'tis ſo I know.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Prethee do not think ſo ill of me.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p:
O Gods! there is nothing but villany in the world, The hearts
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , little hearts, or, as we uſe, narrow hearts.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . of men are ſet upon nothing but Avarice.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Why, I think you are wild.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p: How different is this from the manners of the reſt Of his Life.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p:
By Heaven! thou art
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , crocitas, as one crow doth to another that hath got the Carion before him. mad.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p: A man may ſee by the uncertainty of his countenance, And the rowling of his eyes, the villany he hath done.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p:
Now I know why all this is,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , ſhare with me▪ if I had ſtole any Thing, by this way you think to get half,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . is it not ſo?

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p: How? I rob a thief, what's this?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Well, there is no theft in the buſineſs, what I am About is quite of another kind I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p:
May be you will ſay it was not ſtole but took
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , ſtealing privately, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 to take by force. Away.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p:
Thou art poſſeſſed with a
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Divel ſurely to Talk thus.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.l: There is a third way yet, have you not cozened

Some body by ſome notorious
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , to take by fraud or cunning. fraud of their mony?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: No certainly.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p: Why, then I know not which way to get the truth Out, unleſs you will confeſs.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Why, will you then condemne me before you Hear me?

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p:
Not I friend, but on the contrary would have brought You out of your danger with little coſt, and before the Matter had been known amongſt the people, we would Have ſtopped the Orators
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , he alludes here perhaps to the ſtory of Demoſthenes, who was accuſed for being bribed with a ſilver cup the night before he was to plead, and ſo came muffled up and excuſed himſelf with a ſore throat and horſeneſs. mouths with a little mony.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: You are a kind friend to me, that for the laying Out of a ſhilling would look to get twelve.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p: Methinks I ſee thee now with thy Olive branch in Thy hand, and thy wife and children ſitting about thee Miſerably proſtrate before the Tribunal, We want Pamphilles to draw this Picture methinks.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: I tell thee I am ſo far from taking any thing from Others, that my deſign is to make all honeſt frugal men Richer then they are.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p: Say you ſo, have you ſtole ſuch abundance indeed?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Will you deſtroy me with talking thus.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p: Nay, it ſeems you will deſtroy your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: With what, I tell thee I have Plutus himſelf at My houſe.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p: You Plutus, what Plutus?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Why, the very god Himſelf.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Why, within there.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Why, I tell thee at my houſe.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p: Plutus in thy houſe, go hang thy ſelf, I'le never Believe it.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: By the gods 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p: Wilt thou ſwear by Veſta?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: And by Neptune too.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p: What Neptune, of the Seas?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Yes, and by the other too, if there be one.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.l: And will you lend him now and then
To ſome of your friends?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Soft, yea, it is not come to that yet.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p: Say you ſo, muſt he not ſtir out of your houſe?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Somewhat is firſt to be done.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p: VVhat is that?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.l: VVhy, he muſt be helped to his ſight before
He can go abroad.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p: Is he then blind for certain?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Nothing ſo Sure.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.l: Somewhat I thought was in it, that he never
Could find the way into my houſe.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: All in good time, he will be there now godwilling Shortly.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p: Were we not beſt get a Phyſitian to him?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: VVhat Phyſician is here in this City? here is no art Underſtood here, becauſe there (a) is no reward.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p: Let us conſider.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.l: You will find none but that which I have
Long ſince thought on is beſt, which is to carry
Him to Eſculapius his Temple.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p: You have ſaid well, therefore let us make no delay.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: I am juſt now going Ex. om.

div.stage: Enter Poverty an old Woman, Cramulus, Blapſidamus.

sp.speaker: Pover.
sp.p:
O the
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , hot, and thence in latine for inconſiderateneſs calidum is uſed. impudent wickedneſs that you pitiful Men have undertaken! whither do you fly?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Hercules, what have we here?

sp.speaker: Pover.
sp.p: Nay, I will be the deſtruction of you both, for You have undertaken that which neither God nor Man Durſt go about.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: VVhat art thou that lookeſt ſo pale and lean?

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p:
May be it is
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , contention by Eſculapius.
Erinnis, one of the furies preſented In the
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , he renders it a Tavern Keeper, Tragedies, by her face ſhe ſhould.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: No, ſhe wants a torch in her hand.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p: Nay, then wee'l be bold with her.

sp.speaker: Pover.
sp.p: Whom do you take me for.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.l: A Cauponariam, but for that; in the Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is uſed here by the Etymology 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , a receiver of all company. Bawd, a ſcolding Eggwife,
Or elſe you would never trouble us thus, that never
Have done you any injury.

sp.speaker: Pover.
sp.p: Is it no injury (think you) to throw me out of Every houſe where I come?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.l: Nay, thou art ſure to have one houſe left thee,
The priſon, but tell us what thou art.

sp.speaker: Pover.
sp.p: What puniſhment do you deſerve (think you) for Seeking to take me that am innocent out of the VVorld Thus.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p: VVhat will you ſay if this be a neighbour of mine That keeps a Here 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is uſed. Victualling houſe, and poyſons me and all The ſtreet with baſe wine.

sp.speaker: Pover.
sp.l: I am Poverty, you know me well enough ſure?
For I have frequented many of your houſes a good many
Years I am ſure, and waited diligently upon you.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.l: O Phaebus Apollo! whither ſhall we run,
How ſhall we get away from thee.

sp.speaker: Cram
sp.l: VVhat a pitiful fearful fellow art thou, whither
Doſt thou run, ſtay for ſhame.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p: By no means, not I.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.l: Fie on't, what ſhall one VVoman drive away
Two men?

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.l: VVhy, is there any animal ſo dreadful in the
VVorld, and infectious as Poverty?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Prethee ſtay.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p: By Jove not I.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Nay, but let me tell you 'twill be a ſhamful thing For us to forſake yonder God within, and run I know not VVhither for fear of this old VVitch, let us ſtand to it.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p:
VVith what armes I pray you can we defend our Selves, what breaſt-plate
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , pignus capio, to take pledge, ſecurity. will not ſhe pierce, and what Spear did ever keep her off?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p:
Take courage, our God will give us
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Trophaeum eriget, a cuſtome by a heap of ſtones, or a Wall ſet up where a victory was got. victory Againſt this wicked VVoman, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Pover.
sp.p:
Dare you take of holy
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Piaculum, or an Antidote againſt the plague. things that have ſuch A wickedneſs in hand?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: VVhat do you raile at us for thus, that have done You no injury, you old Divel?

sp.speaker: Pover.
sp.l: Do you think you do me no hurt in ſeeking
Thus to get Plutus his eyes again?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.l: VVhat hurt is it to thee to bring all mankind
A benefit.

sp.speaker: Pover.
sp.p: What good will it bring to men think you?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Firſt of all, we ſhall throw you out of Greece.

sp.speaker: Pover.
sp.p: Throw me out? why, what greater hurt can you do In the World.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.l: Why, it would be a greater to let it alone
And not do it.

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.p: Then before you go any further I will ſhew you the Reaſon of this matter, and demonſtrate that I am the cauſe Of all good to you, and that by my help onely you ſubſiſt In this life, if I do not proceeed as you will, And uſe me as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: What an impudent creature art thou to talk thus!

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.l: If you will ſuffer your ſelf to be taught, I will
Clearly ſhew you, you are out of the way
If you would make the juſt man rich.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p:
O for the Pillory or the
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , the firſt from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , whēce thoſe clubs they beat offenders with ſo called, ſtill uſed in Turky on the feet, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 to make crooked, thence the puniſhment called 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , a diſeaſe in the back, Galen. ſtocks to deliver me Of thee!

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.p: You ought not to complain before you have heard Me.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Who can forbear to cry out miſerably that hears This?

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.p: No wiſe man makes ſuch a Noiſe.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: But will you ſubmit to puniſhment, if you do not Make this good?

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.p: Do what you can invent.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p: 'Tis well.

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.p: But if I have the better of you, you ſhall pay for it.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p: Yes, twenty lives if we had them.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Our two is enough for us to loſe I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.p: I were too blame to ask more. Ex. om.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p: Let us now fall to the matter in hand, and decide The controverſy by true reaſon, laying all jeſts and Scurrility aſide.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p:
In the firſt place then I think it plain to all men, That it is equity that
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 Atheiſts. honeſt men ought to be happieſt, And the unjuſt
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , as they ſay now the ſaints. only to be oppreſt with ill fortune; The which things conſidered, we are now taking the way To it that is moſt probable, for if Plutus can recover his eyes Again, and not go groping up and down thus; He will live Onely amongſt honeſt men, and ſuch as are
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , grown Children. Piouſly Given: now judge you whether there can be a better Counſel then this.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p: I'le be witneſs, no body can complain of this.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p: For if we will but conſider, the lives of Mankind, as Things now ſtand, we ſhall find it madneſs to ſee how for the Moſt part the wicked abound with riches unjuſtly gotten Whileſt honeſt men are ready to ſtarve, and ſpend their Dayes with this Lady; There is therefore no good to 〈…〉 Done, without Plutus have his eyes again.

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.p:
O ye moſt vain and Credulous
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , relating to the firſt life of Mankind in common, poverty maintains the life of propriety againſt it. of all mankind Companions in Dotage and trifles; If that you deſire Should come to paſs, what good would it be to you? fo • If Plutus ſhould ſee again, he would (f) diſtribute
Equally to all men: and then I pray you who would care To ſtudy Arts or Trades? who would build your Ships or Your Coaches? Nay, you muſt even mend your own ſhooes Your ſelves, and plow, and ſow, and reap, or elſe you muſt Not eat, you thought I warrant you to live at eaſe and out Of care.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: You deceive your ſelf, we will keep ſervants to do All this you have recorded.

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.p: Who will ſerve you, or whence will you have them?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Wee'l buy them with our mony.

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.p: Who will ſell them you, when they have as Much mony as you?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.l: Some Merchant of Theſſaly greedy of gain,

That bring us Slaves from thoſe that ſteal
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , a Trade to ſteal Men and Children, which we call Spirits; the word is uſed alſo for Plagiarii, the Latine perhaps uſed it ſo for the nearneſs betwixt libri and liberi. them
Out of the ſuburbs, and by-places I warrant you
Will furniſh us.

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.l: Where will you find any body to ſteal, when no
Body is in want? you may ſteal your ſelves too as well as
Work; and thus by being rich, be much more miſerable
Then you were before.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p: May this miſery fall upon thine own head for Belying us thus.

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.p:
Neither ſhall you ſleep any more upon your fine Beds and Carpets, for indeed you ſhall have none to lie on, Who will make them? for as you ſay every body ſhall have Mony enough: where will you get rich perfumes? you Muſt not think then to walk in ſuch pomp in the ſtreets When you bring your
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , very properly, becauſe it ſignifies the place where the virginity lies. Brides home; and now if you Want all theſe things, judge you whether any body will Account you rich, what will Plutus do you good, and yet From me you enjoy all this and all elſe you have need of, I am the imperious Miſtris of all Artiſts, and ſtand by them Untill they are glad to find any way to ſupport their lives.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p:
Prethee what canſt thou do for any body, but help Them to Biles
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , it ſeems rather that we call Kibes got by coming ſuddainly out of the cold to the fire, which is ſeems was the cuſtome for the poor to get about the fire that made the baths. and Botches, and ſtarve them with vineger, fill them with lice and gnats without number, with A dreadful noiſe, driving away their ſleep, bidding them Ariſe, and try ſome means to prevent ſtarving.

beſides this, inſtead of a whole Cloak thou giveſt them half one, and inſtead of a bed to ſleep in, a Mat to lie awake on, for curtaines and coverlids, rags, and for a pillow a ••• ne, Mallows for bread, and graſs inſtead of Sallets, and •• r an eaſy ſeat, an old barrel with the head beaten out;
Have not I now ſhewed at large the good you do?

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.p:
No, theſe are not of my evils, theſe belong to
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
grabbatum, our Saviour to the man healed in the Goſpel tolle grabbatum, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 Perrottus lectucam. Beggery, not Poverty.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p: Yet we count poverty and beggery are ſiſters.

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.p:
You do perhaps, and it may be you compare Dionyſius
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , it ſeems there was a cuſtome of drying them, as in the Indies and other places they uſe roots for bread. with Thraſibulus; but my life hath none of This in it, it is the begger that hath nothing to live upon The poor live ſparingly upon what they have, And order ſo their affairs, that though they may be ſaid In effect to have
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , are not one, no more than wanting and begging; two very unlike, for Thraſybulus ſtood for the democracy in Athens, and Dionyſius was a Tyrant in Sycily, this alludes to the doctrine of the Cynick Philoſophy, and that of St. Paul, 1 Cor. 2.6, 10.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , having nothing and yet poſſeſſing all things. nothing, yet they want nothing.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p: O what a happy life is this! you tell us of poverty If after all our time ſpent in labour to get and To keep, there ſcarce remain enough to bury us.

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.p: You ſpend your time in cavilling and jeſts, and Not ſeriouſly weigh the matter, nor do you ſeriouſly conſ •••• That I give men better wits and perſons too then Plutus Can; for what does he give, but gouty legs, fat bellies But with me men are active, and ſlender-bodied, and of Warlike ſhape.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p: And all this they get by being farniſhed with Hunger.

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.p: Moreover, for what concernes the modeſty a •• Vertue of living, I can ſay more that they onely belongs To me, and that from Plutus comes nothing but riots a •• Injuring of others.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p:
What is your modeſty, to ſteal and break
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , a Metaphor taken from birds pening their wings when they do not fly. houſe

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p: Nay, the modeſty lies in hiding himſelf when I Hath done.

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.p: Do but obſerve the Orators and Rethoricians when They are poor, how equally and juſtly they carry them ſelves between the People and the Citizens, but then Are no ſooner rich, but they lay Plots preſently to be •••• The lower Sort, and cauſe Wars among them.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Though I do not love thee, I cannot but confeſs this to be true of thee, but yet you ſhall not ſcape us, Going about to prove Poverty better then Wealth.

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.p: Yet you diſprove it not methinks, but wrangle, Jeſt and talk Idly.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Why, tell us then if thou beeſt ſo excellent; Does every body fly from thee ſo?

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.p:
Why? becauſe I would make them better Honeſter, as Children do that avoid their Parents, because
They give them good Counſell and Correction; 'tis a hard Thing for any body to diſtinguiſh good from bad.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Do you think then that Jove doth not diſtinguiſh? You ſee he is rich, and gives it to us too as a bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.p: O ye dull Saturnine wits! why Jove himſelf is A begger, and that I'le prove to you; For if he were rich, when he inſtitutes his Olimpick Games in Greece, ſure he would never reward the Conquerors with an Olive branch and a large oration, But he would give them Gold.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: This ſhews rather how Jupiter loves Gold, by his Parting with it ſo ſparingly; he gives away things of leſs Value, and keeps that for himſelf.

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.p: If it be ſo, you lay a worſe fault to him then Poverty Gives any body, having ſo much wealth notwithſtanding To be ſtill ſo greedy.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: I think Jove will have cauſe to crown you with That Olive brance you ſpoke off for this victory ouer us.

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.p: Well, theſe jeſts contradict nothing of what I ſay, Namely that all good comes of Poverty.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p:
Ask
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , three names for the Moon, Sacrificium, Inſriviis: ſee Mulogy.
Hecate then if it be not beſt to be rich; For the rich make her a feaſt, but the poor do nothing but come in and eat it, therefore let's talk no more, for I am reſolved never to yield, though thou ſhouldeſt overcome me.

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.p:
Then Argos
Argos eſteemed the pooreſt Town in Greece. do thou hear and take compaſſion of me.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p:
Nay, rather call upon Pauſonus thy
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , ſpoke of before ſufficiently. companion.

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.p: Miſerable creature what will become of me!

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p: Get thee from me, and I care not.

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.p: Whether ſhall I go, into what Country?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Into the Stocks, or to the Gallows; come away.Proverbial 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , poorer then Pauſonus.

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.p: The time will come you'l wiſh for me.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.l: Come not before that day,
Till I am weary of being rich.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p: Well, when I am once rich, I'le keep jovial company, feaſt, and bath, and ſit in plenty, and fart at Poverty.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: At length we are got quit of this old Woman, and now Blapſidamus let it be our buſineſs as ſoon as we 〈…〉 , to carry Plutus unto Eſculapius his Temple.

sp.speaker: Blap.
sp.p: We had need diſpatch, leſt ſome body come in and interrupt us.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Within there's Carion, make every thing Ready and bring Plutus to the Temple, with the uſual Ceremonies. Ex. om.

div.head: ACTUS TERTIUS.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
Come all you happy in your old age Who in the dayes of Theſius
Theſius, the firſt Collector of the Athenians into a City from ſmall villages. lived in Poverty and Scarcity of bread, this is the day that I pronounce all Honeſt men happy.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p: O the bleſſed news, that thou art the meſſenger to thy poor companions!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: The buſineſs is brought now about by my Maſter,
For Plutus that you all know hath been ſo long
Blind, now ſees with perfect eyes, and all by the help
Of the moſt famous Eſculapius.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p: Marry, this is pleaſant news.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: 'Twill make you rejoyce whether you will or no.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p: Praiſed be the Son of Apollo. high-born powerful Eſculapius Thou great glory to Mankind. Ex. om.

div.stage: Enter Cramulus his Wife and Carion.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: What a noiſe and knocking is hear to day, I pray
God it be a meſſenger of ſome good?
I have been all day at home expecting Carion,
And now he is come.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Come Miſtris, fetch ſome wine quickly, for I know Firſt 'tis that you love; and then next, becauſe I bring you ſuch a heap of good newes, I deſerve ſome.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Where is it?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I am about to tell it you.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Diſpatch in few words.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Hearken well, & I will tell you all from head to foot

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: So it do not trouble my head, I care not.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: As ſoon as we came to the God Eſculapius Carrying with us (then the moſt unhappy, and now moſt happy) Plutus if any one were ever ſo, firſt of all threw him into the ſea Hejeſts here with the cuſtome in uſe then for any pollution or diſeaſe to waſh in the Sea. Plato reports of Eutipides his companion in his journey to Egypt cured ſo of the Falling-ſickneſs. and waſhed him well.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Would that make an old man as he is happy?
To put him into cold water?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Afterwards when he came before Eſculapius, And had laid our Sacrifices on the Altar, with ſeveral Muſicks playing, we made Plutus lie down every one aſſiſting in the Ceremony.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Were there any more that ſought help from Eſculapius?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
There was one A Rhetorician in Athens, who was troubled with rheum in his eyes. Heoclides, who though blind 'tis thought in robbing and cozenage can exceed the theefes that ſee beſt, beſides many others troubled with all ſorts of evils: now after a little
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 uſed for any kind of ſervant. I think from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , an outward room where ſuch uſe to wait: but it is here 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Prieſt that waited upon the Ceremonies had put out all the lights, and we were laid to Sleep, and a general ſilence commanded; I was only kept Awake by a pleaſant favour that came into my noſe of a Hot Pudding, that the old Woman was eating behind me; At which I crept towards her, to ſee if I could ſteal ſome: And at length, lifting my head a little up, I ſaw a Prieſt go round every Altar in order, and take all the fruit and nuts, and things that was good, and put them in his wallet; Thought I, ſure there is ſome great Sanctity in this kind of Theft, ſo I fell faſter on upon the Pudding.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Thou wretched fellow, waſt not thou afraid Of the God when thou didſt this?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
Yes, I was afraid he would have come with his Robe and his
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Garland and gravely have ſtole my Pudding from me; for that his Prieſt had taught me: But when the old Woman heard the noiſe of my chops Going, ſhe began to reach out her hand as ſhe lay and feel For her Pudding, the which I had now almoſt made an End off, but ſhe feeling the pot there, thought her Pudding Safe, and I crept away as ſilent as a Snake, and with my Belly full layed my ſelf to ſleep.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: And did not Eſculapius yet appear to you?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Not yet: but when he did come, it was my ill luck, my belly growing now burdened with pudding to fall into ſuch a fit of farting.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Was not that enough to make him deſtroy thee?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
No, only Two of Eſculapius his Children, from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , a curing or healing the other from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 a dart or arrow. Jaſo that followed the Gods bluſhed at it, and
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Parocaea ſtopping her noſe, turned aſide: For I muſt tell you though it were in the Church, I could not fart (e) frankinſence.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: But what ſaid the God?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Juſt nothing.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
Is he ſo
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Country bred. courſly bred?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Alas, he is not only a devourer of farts, but feeds Upon Spoken both in reſpect to the offering the entrailes, and likewiſe jeſting at Hypocrates, who uſed the excrements of his patients; likewiſe it relates to a Phyſician his living upon purges. excrements, eats any thing.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Thou wicked fellow.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: After this was all paſt being in great fear of the God ſtill, I hid my ſelf, whilſt with great gravity he adminiſtred to all the diſeaſed according to their ſeveral neceſſities, his boy having brought him a little ſtone mortar, And a box of Inſtruments of Surgery.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Was the box The jeſt of this is, that the Agative Carion uſeth 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ſtony relates both to 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 a Box, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 a Mortar. ſtone too?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Not the box ſtone.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: You lying fellow, you hid your ſelf, and you
You ſay you ſaw all.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Why, I ſaw all through the Prieſts gown which
Wanted not loop holes I aſſure you:
Now to end my ſtory here the oynment was prepared

For Neoclides; of the beſt The jeſt of this is, that the Agative Carion uſeth 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ſtony relates both to 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 a Box, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 a Mortar. garlick three cloves beaten
In a morter as much ſquils this wet with vineger,
And this he applied to Neoclides and to the end historment
Might be greater, he lifted up his eye lids, but he
Stamping and roaring thought to run away, but
Eſculapius laughing, ſaid, Sit ſtill till I releaſe you,
To delay cauſes and betray Clients.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What a lover of the Common-wealth this god is, And how wife.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Next to him he went to Plutus, and wiping firſt his Eyes, and covering his head and face, he gave a ſign with A whiſper, and out came two mighty Snakes.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O monſtrous!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . the ſtatue of Eſculapius, ſometimes with ſerpents, or whether from the proverb 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , ſerpents eyes. Theſe crept under the cloath to his Eyes, as I take it and licked them, and Miſtris, before you Can drink half a dozen glaſſes of wine, Plutus aroſe up with His eye-ſight perfect; I in the mean time clapped My hands for joy, and took my Maſter up in my arms, The God and the Serpents vaniſhed into the Temple, And all that were about Plutus fell to imbrace him, And no man could ſleep any longer for joy; I all the while magnified the God that had made Plutus ſee perfectly, and Neoclide's quite blind.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What a power this Eſculapius hath, but where is Plutus?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
He is coming this way with a number of honeſt People about him, that formerly lived very poorly,
But now Miſtris Plutus ſhakes them all by the hands, but Thoſe that had got wealth unjuſtly he looks awry upon; But 'tis a wonder to ſee how he makes the old fools Leap and frisk before him that can hardly go; And now let us all dance for no man can now ſay to us Our Hogheads are empty of wine, or our Barns of corn.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: By Haccata I will crown thee too for thy news.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Well; diſpatch quickly, for by this the company is At our Gates.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I'le go home that theſe eyes of mine may ſee him.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: And I with theſe leggs of mine will come
Marching before them. Ex. om.

div.stage: Enter Plutus Cramulus and his Wife.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p:
Firſt of all we ſalute the Sun and next this happy Soil of So called from Pallas
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Pallas, together with all the land of Cecrops one of the Attikes.
Cereopis That hath thus kindly received me. It grieves us much to think of our former miſery, And the ill company we have kept, and how we have Wandered up and down; but all this ſhall be amended And the world ſhall ſee it was much againſt my will To be kept in the hands of bad men.

sp.speaker: Crem.
sp.p: Out upon't, what creatures men are that are friends To a man only according to his ſuccceſs, every one I meet Now ſmiles on me, and my hands are almoſt ſhaked off: Who hath met me in the ſtreet to day without a complement? and all the old fools get about me and frisk.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Right worthy man, bleſſing attend thee, and us all, According to our Countries cuſtome I have brought A ſmall banquet to refreſh thee with.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: No ſure, the firſt houſe I go with my eye ſight into, Ought to receive from me, and not I from it.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Will you deſpiſe our good will.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: Within by the fire ſide, when we are rid of this Rabbel of company, we ſhall have more leiſure.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Indeed you ſay well, for they had like to have had Me down for my Nuts and Apples but now. Ex. om.

div.head: ACTUS QUARTUS.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
What a pleaſure there is in living rich, eſpecially to ſuch as we that ſpend what we will; have ſtill
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , the Scolio renders this from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 to us that carry nothing but of our houſe; but there is I think a better meaning in it, which is, becauſe there is a god in the houſe, every thing is by Miracle repleniſhed ſtill as it waſtes; ſo the Prophet 2 King. 4. of the cruſe of Oyle. never the leſs left for it, fetch in nothing, but every thing runs in as it were of it ſelf; our barns are full of corn, our Hogsheads full of wine, the jars full of oyle, pots full of Spicknard, and our purſes full of mony, our rotten earthen Pots are now all ſilver, and the kitchin ſhines like Ivory. We ſervants now in ſtead of Counters play at
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , even equal in parts. even or odd with
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Attick Coin, half a dram. Gold, nor do we now wipe our tailes
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , ſtones, or rather ſhels. with Pibbles, but choice herbs moſt delightfully.

The worſt is, my Maſter yonder within with his golden crown On, is ſacrificing
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , garleek; and therfore I think it is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 a Medicinal hearb, and good for the tenderneſs of thoſe parts.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , ſacrificing a Bull. a hog, a ram and a goat within, and There is ſuch ſmoak and ſtink in the houſe, I was fain to Come crying out.

div.stage: Enter Juſtus his Boy and Carion.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Come child, follow me, and let us go to this God.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: VVho have we here making ſuch haſt towards us?

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: A man formerly miſerable, but now happy.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: He hath a good honeſt face.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Yes ſure, and am that I ſeem.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: VVell, what's thy buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: I would ſpeak with your god a word or two, for I have received a great deal of good from him; I was left well by my Father, and ſupplied my friends In their neceſſities, and thought that they might be uſeful To me again in time of need.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And what you fell into want, I warrant preſently.

sp.speaker: Just.
sp.p: Moſt certain, I did ſo.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: How did you do then, I warrant you were miſerably Uſed?

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Ye hit it right; for I was ſtrongly perſwaded That they that had ſo liberally taſted of my kindneſs in My proſperity, would make ſome return when my turn Of ſuffering came, but they all looked awry upon me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And laughed at thee I warrant.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p:
They did ſo, when they ſaw me
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 to dry 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , dryneſs of pots. wither away.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: They'l do ſo no more, I warrant thee now.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: I am therefore come to thank Plutus for it.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But prethee, what is the reaſon thy Boy carries this Old torn Cloak after thee?

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: I come to conſecrate this to the memory of Plutus.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
'Tis the Cloak I warrant thou wert firſt
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and thence 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , it was the cuſtome to hang up the cloaths in Ceres Temple, that thou firſt came thither in. initiated In amongſt the gods.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: No, not ſo; but I have ſuffered cold in it this Thirteen years I am ſure,

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And what are theſe old ſhooes for?

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Why, theſe are a year old too.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And ſo theſe are ſacred too.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: By Jupiter, I think ſo.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: You'l bring him a brave gift. Ex. om.

sp.speaker: Syc.
sp.p:
O
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 fearful, the Greeks uſe that often for Miſerable fear, being the greateſt of Miſeries to Mankind. miſerable man that I am, thrice miſerable, Nay, a hundred times over miſerable!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: O Apollo and the reſt of ye, what doth this fellow aile?

sp.speaker: Syc.
sp.p: Why, I am undone in this one day, and have loſt All, and all by this god of yours; but if there be any Law left, I'le have him made blind again as he was.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: This is ſome knave I perceive oppreſt with ill
Fortune for his ill manners.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Let him deſervedly then periſh like a thief as he is.

sp.speaker: Syc.
sp.p: Where is he that hath promiſed to make us all Equally rich in one day, upon condition he might have his Eyes again, and hath in doing ſo, made us ten times more Miſerable then we were before, I'm ſure ſome of us at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: 'Tis becauſe thou art a fool and a wicked fellow.

sp.speaker: Syc.
sp.p: None of you were counted wiſe I'm ſure till you got mony.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
How fierce this Sycophant is? his profeſſion now will not get him
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 adverb and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 famine. bread, and that's it.

sp.speaker: Syc.
sp.p:
You ſhall never ſcape me this day, I will have you Before the Juſtice, and hear you upon the wrack
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ſtretched out from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , all of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 to turn the ſame way by which men afflict one another, now it ſeems were formerly uſed. confeſs the horrible miſchiefs you have done.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Alas, go and lament thy own condition.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p:
And by Jove
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , uſed in Holy Sripture for Saviour, Salvation. let Plutus be acknowledged of all Greece this day for throwing out all of your profeſſion.

sp.speaker: Syc.
sp.p:
O wretch that I am, what muſt I make you ſport too? I pray you, where had you that new Cloak you have on? Yeſterday, one
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , to rub or crumble away. thred-bare ſerved your turn.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p:
I fear thee not, I have got now a ring ofThe Ancients had great ſuperſtition to rings made and conſtilated for ſeveral things, as that of Gygas; Eudamꝰ a Phyloſopher made ſome good againſt flattery. Eudam ••
That I wear here as a charm againſt thee.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But yet againſt the biting of a Sycophant, I doubt Man hath no remedy of prevention.

sp.speaker: Syc.
sp.p: Are theſe ſcorns to be endured! what do you ſtay here for, for no good to any body I am ſure?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Not to do you any good I am ſure.

sp.speaker: Syc.
sp.p: No, but to live upon me, and ſup to night of that Which ſhould have For lately he was the only man in Greece at other mens Tables. been mine

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: O then thou wilt ſplit with malice, for thou art Like now to have nothing elſe in thy guts.

sp.speaker: Syc.
sp.p: You ſay nothing, but all this while I ſmell a good Supper within of all manner of The Latine interprets it ſo, but the word is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 fruit, from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 to cut. fiſh and fleſh.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What's this he ſmels?

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: I believe 'tis rather hunger and cold that's coming Towards him, that he ſmels through the holes of his torn Cloak, then any thing elſe.

sp.speaker: Syc.
sp.l: Muſt I ſuffer all this reproach, O the gods!
That an honeſt man and a lover of his Country ſhould
Be thus uſed.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: You a lover of your Country?

sp.speaker: Syc.
sp.p: Yes, no man more.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Anſwer me then.

sp.speaker: Syc.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Are you a husband-man?

sp.speaker: Syc.
sp.p: Do you think me mad to lead ſuch a painful life?

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Are you a Merchant then?

sp.speaker: Syc.
sp.p: I can counterfeit one, if need be.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Do you then profeſs any art?

sp.speaker: Syc.
sp.p: O Jove not I!

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Which way doſt thou live then, that haſt nothing To do?

sp.speaker: Syc.
sp.p: Why, I take all buſineſs both publick and private Upon me.

sp.speaker: Just.
sp.p: Who entruſts you?

sp.speaker: Syc.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis my own pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Thou art alwayes medling where thou haſt nothing To do, and art hated of all men: with what confidence Canſt thou then profeſs thy ſelf an honeſt man?

sp.speaker: Syc.
sp.p:
Ye
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , a leagull. fool, do not I deſerve well enough of the Common-wealth, think you, according to my place and Power?

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Yes, if medling with other mens buſineſs, and having none of ones own, be a good quality.

sp.speaker: Syc.
sp.p: 'Tis every mans buſineſs to ſee the Lawes obeyed, and puniſh thoſe that offend.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: The City appoints Judges for that purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Syc.
sp.p: Yes, but who ſhall find them work? that is, bring in Offenders.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: He that will for me, for 'tis an Office bad enough.

sp.speaker: Syc.
sp.p: Well, I am that man, and therefore judge if the whole buſineſs of the Common-wealth runs not through my hands.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: This City had an evil But for ſpies and falſe witneſſes Courts of Juſtice could not ſtand. inſtrument of thee; But wert not thou better live without this trouble, in peace?

sp.speaker: Syc.
sp.p:
O no, 'tis a ſheepiſh
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , preſidente. life to live without exerciſing our wits.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: And wilt thou never change this mind?

sp.speaker: Syc.
sp.p:
Not, if you will give me your Plutus that you have got,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . and Battus his Sylphium to boot.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Come, Battus built the City Cyrenes, for the which the Affricans ſacrificed 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . I think the hearb Benzoin, and it was afterwards the reverſe of his coin, and I believe there lies moſt of the fancy. give me your Cloak.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Friend, he ſpeaks to you.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: And next your (f) ſhooes.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Again he ſpeaks to you.

sp.speaker: Syc.
sp.p: Will no body help me?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Yes, I am ready to help you off with them.

sp.speaker: Syc.
sp.p: I am undone.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: See now what you get by medling with others Buſineſs is all ſo juſt loſt again.

sp.speaker: Syc.
sp.p: Take heed what you do, I have witneſs here by How I am uſed.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Nay, your falſe witneſs have now forſaken you.

sp.speaker: Syc.
sp.p: Wo is me, if I am left alone to you too!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Now howl and roar, doſt hear Juſtus? now give me thy old Cloak, and wee'l put it upon the Sycophants back.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: That cannot be, man; I have, you know, conſecrated it to Plutus.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: By no means, 'twill become this fellow much better, and wee'l get a better Cloak for Plutus.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: But what ſhall I do with my old ſhooes?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Wee'l hang thoſe in his fore-head.

sp.speaker: Syc.
sp.p: Well, I ſee I muſt for the preſent be gone, for ye are too ſtrong for me, but I'le return and be revenged upon you and your god, for altering the government of Mankind, thus without asking the Senate or the Towns advice.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p:
Now you are got into my
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 rather my Armour or my inſtruments, ſo in Holy Scriptures, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , inſtruments of unrighteouſnes. cloaths, run betimes, and get my place about the bath
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , to take or bind by the ſtones. and keep you warm; It hath been my place this many years I am ſure.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
'Tis his beſt if he can, but the Bath-keeper will quickly take hold
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , a ſhe Sycophant or bawde. of him and throw him out of dores, I warrant you, come let us in and ſalute our Plutus.

div.stage: Enter Old Woman, Chorus of Countrymen, and Cramulus.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Good honeſt old Gentlemen, tell me if this be the way to the new god they talk of.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p: Ye are now come to the very houſe, good young Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: May I be ſo bold to call to ſpeak with ſome of the Houſe?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: That's needleſs, for I am going in; but what's your buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: I am under a great deal of miſery, and have been ſo ever ſince this god firſt began to have his ſight again.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p:
What's the matter, ſure this is ſomething amongſt the
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , to play at lots, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , you drink by letters; it was it ſeems as was noted, a cuſtome to chuſe Judges by letters put into a Box, and the drinkers get the trick to do ſo. women, that the Sycophant is amongſt men and of the ſame calling.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Alas not I!

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p:
Then thou art ſome ſhe
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , I am burned up, and therefore his reply is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , whence is this burning up, of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . drunkard.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: You jeſt with my afflictions, and that's worſt of all, I am withered away (e) with love.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Prethee who hath withered thee?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: You muſt know, there was a young fellow with an honeſt good face, but poor, yet the truth is he gave me what I wanted, and I ſupplied him with his neceſſities.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: What were they?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Why, truely he was not very importunate, only ſometimes he wanted mony to buy him a Cloak, and ſometimes a pair of Shooes, and ſometimes his Siſter and his Mother wanted cloaths, and ſometimes bread.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Call you this nothing, this was love indeed.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Yes indeed, for he ſaid he asked theſe things not for their value, but as they were mine, and ſo wore my very ſhooes for my ſake, and to put him in mind of me.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: This was a wonderful lover.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: But now alas, his love is quite vaniſhed, for but now I ſent him Cheeſcakes, and bad the meſſenger tell him I would ſee him to night.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: And what ſaid he, prethee?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p:
Truly, he ſent me my Cheeſcakes again, and bid me be ſure never to come to him more, and withal added this proverb, that once the
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , the ſtory is Polycrates K. of Samia, being to make war, counſelled the Oracle whither he ſhould take the Mileſians help, but he was anſwered, they were once ſtrong; ſo it grew proverbial to all that were worſted. Mileſii indeed were Powerful.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p:
A crafty fellow, he ſcorns ordinary
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , ſignifieth lentiles. fair now, but would have devoured any thing when he was poor.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: And yet heretofore this man would be at my Chamber dore every day.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: To ſee what he could ſteal, I warrant.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: No, he ſwore it was onely to here my voice.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: By which he thought to hear ſome gift was coming.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p:
And when he ſaw me ſad, he would call me his
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , words of fondneſs. Minion, his Deer.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: This was when he had got thy ſhooes on, I warrant.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: And at Ceres feaſt, when we were in the coach together, if any body did but give me a look, I was beaten for it all day, ſo jealous he was of me.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: He would have no body enjoy your goods but he.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: He would tell me I had ſuch fine white hands.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: When they were reaching him out mony.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p:
He ſaid my skin
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , wine of a famous Iſland in Greece. naturally ſmelt ſweet.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Then thou hadſt ſome trick to ſweat wine.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p:
He ſaid I had lovely
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , a good look. eyes.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p:
This fellow is no fool, he knows how to ſtir up an Old
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , the ſow's grunting for the bore. womans luſt, this was the right food to it.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Now gentlemen conſider, whether your god, do not do unjuſtly, to ſee a poor woman under theſe afflictions, and not help her.

sp.speaker: Cram
sp.p: Say what thou wouldeſt have him do, and wee'l ſend for him.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: 'Tis juſt that he ſhould make this young fellow deſerve as well of me, as I have done of him.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Why, he pays thee all at night ſtill I hope.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Alas, he promis'd whilſt he lived he would never forſake me.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: He hath kept his word, for I warrant he doth not believe thou art now fit to be called a living creature.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p:
Indeed I am
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , to extend, I am waſted. waſted with ſorrow.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Or rather dryed up with it and ſhrunk.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: You may draw me through a ring.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: That ring muſt be as big as the hoop of a Sive.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: See yonder he comes of whom I complain thus, Hee's going to ſome feaſt I warrant.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p:
It ſeems ſo, for he is very
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Coronā & facem. fine.

sp.speaker: Young.
sp.p: Save ye Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Let's here what he will ſay.

sp.speaker: Young.
sp.p: O Miſtris mine! how ſuddenly are you altered? Grown gray I proteſt, ſince I ſaw you.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: O miſerable woman that I am, how I am abuſed!

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: What, is it ſuch a long time ſince he ſaw you?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: How long think you? he was with me but yeſterday.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Then this man differs from all others, for the More drunk he is, the quicker his ſenſes are.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: O no, this is of late his uſual humour.

sp.speaker: Young
sp.p: O Neptune, what waves, what wrinkles haſt thou got in thy forehead!

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Prethee do not bring the light ſo near.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: She ſays well, for if one ſpark ſhould chance to fall upon thee, thou wouldſt burn and crack like a piece of an Olive tree.

sp.speaker: Young.
sp.p: How ſayeſt, wilt thou have a bout with me?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Where thou fooliſh fellow.

sp.speaker: Young.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: At what game?

sp.speaker: Young.
sp.p: At even or odd, how many teeth haſt in thy head?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: I can devine that, not above three or four, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Young.
sp.p: Still thou art able to crack nuts, for a Mill hath but one tooth.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p:
You are uncivil thus to
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , to waſh, or a privy-houſe, or common-ſhore. empty all your villany and ill language upon me thus.

sp.speaker: Young.
sp.p: You muſt get ſome body to make you clean again then.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p:
O waſh her not by any means, for if her
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that we call Ceres, and the ſame uſed now adaies. paint were waſhed off, we ſhould ſee a face would fright us.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: For a man of your age you ſeem not to be very wiſe methinks.

sp.speaker: Young.
sp.p:
He hath been
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , put his hands in thy neck. tempting thee, and playing with thee I believe, and thou findeſt he is old and can do nothing and ſo thou deſpiſeſt him.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: By Venus! never touched me, thou wicked fellow.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: No no, I were mad to offer it, that were to make a Quarrel between you and your Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Young.
sp.p: Alas, I defie you for that, I love her ſo it's impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: She accuſes you though.

sp.speaker: Young.
sp.p: Me, of what?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Of all manner of reproaches, and that you hit her in the teeth with that proverb, that once the Mileſii were ſtrong.

sp.speaker: Young.
sp.p: Well, you ſtrive to win my girle from me, I ſee, But I will not contend with you for her.

sp.speaker: Cram
sp.p: You ſlight her, I ſee.

sp.speaker: Young.
